content.title: TRANSACTIONS

content.text: Warsaw's new archbishop, Stanislaw W. Wielgus, caught in Eastern Europe's widening witch hunt for former Communist secret police informers, admitted Friday that he had collaborated with the Sluzba Bezpieczenstwa, or Security Service, known as the S.B.  ''Before you today, I confess to the mistake committed by me years ago, just as I have confessed to the Holy Father,'' Bishop Wielgus said in an open letter to Polish Catholics. ''By the fact of this entanglement, I have damaged the church.''  He said he compounded that damage by denying ''facts of this cooperation'' in recent days.  Bishop Wielgus insisted, however, that he had neither spied on anyone nor harmed anyone. He said the only thing he ever did was to inform the secret police of his agenda during foreign academic meetings and to promise not to take part in anti-Communist activities.  He said it was up to Pope Benedict XVI to decide whether he would keep his new job, which he took up Friday.  The bishop is to be officially elevated to archbishop during a ceremony on Sunday in Warsaw at St. John's Cathedral, though many voices in Poland have called for him to step down.  The Warsaw archbishopric is a particularly symbolic institution in the former Soviet bloc. The Polish church, together with the Polish-born Pope John Paul II, were crucial supporters of the pro-democracy Solidarity movement, which helped bring down the totalitarian system and end the cold war.  Confirmation that the archbishop collaborated is doubly troubling because the Polish secret police murdered a charismatic anti-Communist priest from the archdiocese, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, in 1984. Warsaw's departing archbishop, Cardinal Jozef Glemp, waged a quiet battle with the Communist Party in those years.  Many historians argue that a significant segment of the clergy in Poland and other Eastern bloc countries collaborated to varying degrees with the secret services. Priests have recently been added to those segments of society under scrutiny in several countries during recent efforts to expose former Communist collaborators.  Two years ago, files surfaced showing that the Rev. Mieczyslaw Malinski, who had been close to John Paul II, worked for the S.B. in the 1980s. Several other prominent priests have since been accused of having been informers, and some have admitted that they had links to the secret police. The Polish church publicly apologized last year for priests who collaborated with the S.B., but has tried to keep their names secret.  The uproar over Bishop Wielgus's past began shortly after Pope Benedict picked him in early December to succeed Cardinal Glemp as Warsaw's archbishop. A Polish daily newspaper, Gazeta Polska, reported Dec. 20 that the bishop, 67, had spied on dissidents and fellow clerics for more than two decades, until Communism collapsed in 1989.  Both Bishop Wielgus and the Vatican sought to deflect the accusations by saying his involvement with the secret police had been nothing out of the ordinary for people traveling abroad during the Communist era. Leading representatives of the Polish clergy denounced the accusations against him.  But Poland's human rights ombudsman, Janusz Kochanowski, said Thursday that there was evidence in the secret police archives that Bishop Wielgus had knowingly cooperated with Communist authorities. Rzeczpospolita, one of Poland's most respected newspapers, published documents showing that he had met with police agents more than 50 times in one five-year period.  Even Poland's Catholic Church Historical Commission issued a statement on Friday, saying, ''There are numerous, substantial documents confirming Stanislaw Wielgus's willingness for a conscious and secret cooperation with the Communist security forces.''  The commission said that there was no evidence that Bishop Wielgus's actions harmed anyone, and that the documents would be sent to the Vatican for further study.  Monsignor Wielgus first admitted Friday that he had signed a cooperation statement with the secret police in 1978 under pressure by a ''brutal intelligence officer'' when he was seeking permission to travel to Munich. ''That was my moment of weakness,'' he wrote.  But he accused the secret police of falsifying documents that cast him as a more eager, useful collaborator than he actually was.  ''The personality ascribed to me in the intelligence service documents is so far from the truth that I would never have recognized myself,'' he wrote.  Those claims are not far-fetched. Almost from the moment the Iron Curtain fell, the nations of the former Communist bloc have been steeped in controversies over the files of their secret police forces. The documents are often elliptical and incomplete, and were sometimes embellished by secret police officers eager to impress their superiors, experts say.  The documents published by Rzeczpospolita and other newspapers suggest that Bishop Wielgus was recruited by the S.B. in 1967 when he was a philosophy student at the University of Lublin in eastern Poland, more than a decade before he signed the cooperation agreement. Newspapers cited other documents in which the S.B. claimed he had given them information about activities at the university, where he later served as a professor of medieval philosophy.  The newspapers claimed that some documents referred to Bishop Wielgus by the code names Grey, Adam and Adam Wysocki. They said he received training and was rewarded for his collaboration with a grant to study in Munich.  Later Friday, Bishop Wielgus issued another statement, which was broadcast by Vatican Radio's Polish service, in which he said he had collaborated so that he could travel abroad for his academic research.  ''I'm not trying to justify anything, I know that I shouldn't have had any relations with the Communist regime's secret services,'' he said. ''At the time I thought I had to continue my important scientific research and acquire sound training for the good of the church.''  The Vatican has continued to support the embattled prelate.  ''The Holy See, in deciding the nomination of the new archbishop of Warsaw, took into consideration all the circumstances of his life, including those regarding his past,'' the Vatican said in a statement on Friday, repeating the position it has taken for the past month.  The statement said Benedict ''has every confidence in Bishop Stanislaw Wielgus and in full conscience entrusted him the mission of pastor of the archdiocese of Warsaw.''
content.title: Ties to Communist Secret Police Snare Polish Bishop

content.text: In March, necessity moved Carmen Laureano and her two daughters from Florida to New York City.  Ms. Laureano, 36, lost her job when the day care center where she had worked for about three years came under new ownership. ''Everything changed for me; everything was down,'' she said.  She moved with her girls, Luz and Franchesca Rivera, 12 and 10, to the Bronx, hoping to stay with her mother. But the young family could not stay in her mother's housing complex for the elderly. She and the girls quickly found themselves homeless and entered the shelter system.  ''For the people living in the shelter it's not that easy to get out,'' Ms. Laureano said. But she did. With persistence, determination and some help from Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, Ms. Laureano has made a new city her family's new home.  In June, they moved into a one-bedroom apartment in the Bronx, and Ms. Laureano gave the bedroom to her daughters so they ''could have privacy.'' Framed family photos hang in the living room, where Ms. Laureano sleeps.  For a year, the $925 monthly rent is covered by Housing Stability Plus, a Department of Homeless Services program that offers a five-year subsidy that decreases gradually each year. Ms. Laureano is already worried about paying next year's rent.  ''I'm going to start studying because in one year I have to work,'' she said. Since moving here in the spring, Ms. Laureano has spent her time finding housing, schools and medical services for her family and caring for her daughters. She plans to take computer classes with the help of Catholic Charities. ''I have to start paying rent by myself.''  Her willingness to work is real, but so are her worries. Caring for Franchesca takes a special effort. ''Franchesca is a special girl,'' Ms. Laureano said. A lack of oxygen to her daughter's brain during birth caused mild mental retardation and behavioral problems. Ms. Laureano must be home when Franchesca returns from school. ''I have to be here, at 3; I have to be downstairs,'' she said.  Finding the right school to meet her daughter's needs was also a challenge. When they arrived in New York, Franchesca was mistakenly put in mainstream classes.  ''My daughter was in regular class and it was a mess,'' Ms. Laureano said. Franchesca was disruptive and could not do the work. ''It was hard for her, for the teacher, for the students.''  Ms. Laureano found help and a feeling of home, at the Thorpe Family Residence in the Bronx, where the family lived while it was homeless. The Thorpe residence is affiliated with Catholic Charities, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The Thorpe staff connected Ms. Laureano to the services she needed. ''They give you support,'' she said. ''They help you out a lot. They are like a family.''  Counselors at Thorpe referred her to medical and educational services for Franchesca, and Ms. Laureano did considerable work following through. ''I have to start from the shelter, then I have to talk with the social worker to see if she could help me,'' she said, ''I went to two schools before I get that school.''  The school is Public School 161, where Franchesca started in the fall. She is in Spanish-language special education classes with her peers, working at a first-grade level. The family is from Puerto Rico, and Ms. Laureano taught herself English in Florida. Luz, in the sixth grade, speaks both Spanish and English, but is in some bilingual classes to provide better comprehension.  Franchesca, who speaks Spanish, was crying on the first day. But, by the second day, ''she was the friend of the teacher,'' Ms. Laureano said.  Being taught in Spanish and working with children at her level has made a big difference for Franchesca.  ''Mommy, Mommy, I know how to read!'' Ms. Laureano remembered her daughter announcing one day after school. The family celebrated, ''We made a party,'' Ms. Laureano said.  Ms. Laureano was also referred to a clinic for her daughter's mental health issues, and Franchesca received new medication to control her behavior. Now, Franchesca is calm and more focused, Ms. Laureano said. ''She could really learn. She could hear. Without the medication she just wants to fight.''  The family's monthly income is limited to $145 in public assistance and $255 in food stamps. With the help of staff members at Thorpe, Ms. Laureano is applying for Social Security supplemental income for Franchesca.  Two weeks after school began, the family received $425 in Neediest Cases money for school clothes, shoes, socks and underwear. The family also bought four folding chairs to put around a dining table. ''Thank you for all the help,'' Ms. Laureano said.  Franchesca is shy around strangers. She stayed in the bedroom and sometimes hid under the covers. She is not shy with her family. ''No way,'' Ms. Laureano laughed. ''It's different when we three are alone.''  Previously recorded: $7,109,434.83  Recorded Monday: 23,675.42  Total: $7,133,110.25  Last year to date: $6,503,473.98  HOW TO HELP  Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund should be sent to 4 Chase Metrotech Center, 7th Floor East, Lockbox 5193, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11245, or any of these organizations:  BROOKLYN BUREAU OF COMMUNITY SERVICE  285 Schermerhorn Street  Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217  CATHOLIC CHARITIES, DIOCESE OF BROOKLYN AND QUEENS  191 Joralemon Street  Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201  CATHOLIC CHARITIES OF THE ARCHDIOCESE OF NEW YORK  1011 First Avenue  New York, N.Y. 10022  CHILDREN'S AID SOCIETY  105 East 22nd Street  New York, N.Y. 10010  COMMUNITY SERVICE SOCIETY OF NEW YORK  105 East 22nd Street  New York, N.Y. 10010  FEDERATION OF PROTESTANT WELFARE AGENCIES  281 Park Avenue South  New York, N.Y. 10010  UJA-FEDERATION OF NEW YORK  Church Street Station  P.O. Box 4100  New York, N.Y. 10261-4100  Donations may be made with a credit card by phone at (800) 381-0075 or online, courtesy of NYCharities.org, an Internet donations service, at www.nytimes.com/neediest or www.nycharities.org/neediest. For instructions on how to donate stock to the fund, call (212) 556-1137 or fax (212) 556-4450.  No agents or solicitors are authorized to seek contributions for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.  The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to the charities, which use them to provide services and cash assistance to the poor.  Contributions to the fund are deductible on federal, state and city income taxes to the extent permitted by law.  To delay may mean to forget.  Correction:  January 26, 2007, Friday  A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about Carmen Laureano, a Bronx woman who received money for clothing and furniture from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the subject of the picture in some copies. She was Luz Rivera, Ms. Laureano's 12-year-old daughter, not Ms. Laureano.
content.title: The Neediest Cases; After Getting Family Out of Shelter, Mother Has a New Challenge: Paying the Rent

content.text: GRECO--Dr. Gabriel, 91, loving husband of Norma, he passed away on Friday, January 6, in his sleep after a lingering illness. He was a man of infinite wisdom, integrity and great dignity. He was a skilled ophthalmologist and had great compassion. He was on the staffs of Bellevue, Tish Hospital, St. Vincent and Cabrini. He was a warm, loving friend and will be missed by all. Besides his wife, he is survived by his two sisters, Marion Macina and Rosalie Pasquale, and nieces, nephews and cousins. Services will be held Monday & Tuesday at Chas Peter Nagel Funeral home in NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Diabetes Research Institute Foundation.  $(6$)GRECO--Gabriel J. M.D., beloved husband of Norma, devoted brother of Marion Macina and Rosalie Pasquale, survived by many nieces, nephews and many wonderful friends. Reposing at Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St. NYC, between 1st and 2nd Ave. Mass of Christian Bural. St Joseph's Church. 87 St between 1st and York. Wednesday 10AM. Entombment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Visiting hours, Monday and Tuesday 2-5, 7-9pm.
content.title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRECO, DR. GABRIEL

content.text: In Thursday's column you had the chance to pick West's opening lead against a small slam. Now you can select something against a grand slam, seven spades. What would be your choice?  On Thursday Harold Rosenson of West Palm Beach, Fla., led a low trump from queen-doubleton against a small slam. This imaginative choice did not generate a trump trick, but it defeated the contract when declarer failed to play double-dummy. Any side-suit lead would have made declarer's task easy.  That column resulted in a small flurry of e-mail messages. During an open trial in the '70s, someone led low from queen-doubleton of trump against a grand slam. After dummy played low, his partner would not put up the king from king-doubleton, so the grand made.  In the '80s a player underled king-doubleton of trump against a grand slam, confident the ace was on his left. There was bad news, good news and bad news. Dummy did not have the trump ace; it was nestling in declarer's hand -- ugh. But partner had queen-doubleton of trump -- aah. After dummy played low, so did third hand -- ugh, ugh.  And another player in the '80s underled king-doubleton of trump against a grand slam. There was good news, better news and best news. The ace was in the dummy. Partner had queen-doubleton. And after dummy played low, partner eventually put up the queen to hold the trick. Attempts to find these full layouts have failed -- memories get hazy over the decades.  These deals do highlight an advantage of Roman Key Card Blackwood, which uncovers not only the four aces but also the trump king and trump queen. These ''no-play'' grand slams are now avoided.  The diagramed deal occurred during the 1977 Bermuda Bowl world team championship in Manila. It was described in ''Trump Leads'' by Dr. George Rosenkranz (Devyn Press, 1986). North's three-spade rebid was forcing. South, not playing Roman Key Card Blackwood, blasted into seven spades.  If South had been using that convention, he would have known that the trump queen was missing and presumably would have settled for six spades. But there is a strong case for bidding seven anyway. It has always been traditional to lead a trump against a grand slam. So if West leads a trump, it picks up the queen for you. And if West leads a side suit, declarer plays him for the trump queen.  South would presumably have done that here -- except that the American expert Mike Passell did lead a low trump. Declarer, thinking East must have the spade queen, called for dummy's ten, taking the trick. Then he cashed dummy's ace -- and ruefully nodded his head when East discarded.  Presumably West has led from two or three low trumps, or from four to the queen. Perhaps South should have led dummy's low trump at Trick 2. If East follows suit, South puts in his nine -- an interesting way to play in a grand slam. But when East discards, declarer can win with his king and finesse on the way back through West.  In the other room, Passell's teammates stopped in six spades, so his team gained 14 international match points instead of losing 11.  Bridge
content.title: Defending A Slam Again, Only This Time It's Grand

content.text: MANY investors have been heeding market strategists' advice to reduce portfolio risk by putting more money into stable, high-quality, dividend-paying stocks.  But instead of plowing this money into large-capitalization companies based in the United States, investors have redirected much of it into shares of blue-chip foreign companies based largely in Western Europe and Japan.  Indeed, foreign large-cap blend funds -- which primarily invest in blue-chip growth and value stocks in developed markets -- were the most popular category of funds through the first 11 months of 2006, according to the Financial Research Corporation in Boston.  Foreign large-blend funds attracted $43.8 billion of net new money during this stretch. By comparison, highflying diversified emerging-market stock funds attracted $6.6 billion and domestic large-blend funds drew $4 billion, according to Financial Research.  But does investing in blue chips abroad achieve the same results for a portfolio as investing in big, high-quality domestic stocks?  The answer is still no, given the currency risks that you inevitably take on when investing abroad. Yet a growing number of people argue that foreign and domestic stocks are becoming more alike, given the increased correlation among the world's markets.  Since 1970, for example, the Morgan Stanley Capital International EAFE index, for European, Australian and Far Eastern stocks, has returned 11.6 percent a year, on average. That is nearly identical to the annualized gain of 11.2 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index of domestic blue chips.  But keep in mind that those slightly higher gains came with slightly higher risk, as foreign stocks on their own are still more volatile than domestic equities.  Sometimes, a modest dose of a risky asset can make an entire portfolio less volatile. From 1970 to 2005, a 100 percent stock portfolio invested in the S.& P. 500 would have earned 11.1 percent, annualized, according to S.& P. And that is with a so-called standard deviation -- a popular measure of volatility -- of 16.8. But by moving 25 percent of that money from the S.& P. 500 to the EAFE index, the portfolio would have earned 11.4 percent a year, on average, with a slightly lower standard deviation of 16.4.  Add too much, however, and more volatility enters the mix. In this case, had 75 percent of the equity stake been invested in the EAFE index and 25 percent in the S.& P. 500, the portfolio would have earned the same 11.4 percent, annualized, from 1970 to 2005. But the portfolio's volatility would have shot up to 19.1.  This shows that while the global markets may be moving more in sync, ''the world markets aren't completely integrated yet,'' said James D. Peterson, vice president of the Schwab Center for Investment Research in San Francisco.  Consider the recent performance of foreign and domestic blue chips. Over the last five years, the average foreign large-blend fund returned 13.8 percent a year, on average, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracker, as many foreign economies have grown faster than that of the United States and as the dollar has weakened of late.  By comparison, domestic large-cap blend funds advanced only 6.3 percent a year, on average, during this stretch. And last year, foreign blue-chip funds soared 25.1 percent, beating the returns of domestic blue-chip funds by more than 10 percentage points.  Arguably, much of the investor interest in foreign blue chips can be attributed to their outperformance, not to their similarities to their domestic counterparts.  ''A lot of people just want to be exposed to foreign because it's been doing so well,'' said Ronald W. Rogé, a financial planner in Bohemia, N.Y. ''It's performance chasing.''  To be sure, the correlation between the S.& P. 500 and the EAFE index has been 0.8 over the last three years, according to Morningstar. On paper, that is fairly high, because a correlation of 1.0 implies that two assets are moving in perfect tandem.  But consider that over this same stretch, the correlation between the S.& P. 500 and the Russell 2000 index of small domestic stocks was actually greater, 0.83, according to Morningstar. Yet investors take it on faith that large-cap and small-cap stocks are entirely different asset classes.  There are several reasons for continuing to treat foreign and domestic blue-chip stocks separately. ''A big reason is the issue of currency,'' Mr. Peterson said.  Investors who put money to work in a foreign market should consider that market's volatility, as well as that of the currency in which its stocks trade.  In 2006, the EAFE index rose 13.8 percent when measured in local currencies, according to MSCI. But for Americans to make an investment abroad, money must first be converted from dollars to those local currencies to buy the securities. And when it comes time to sell, the money has to be reconverted back into dollars.  In dollar terms, the EAFE index actually returned much more last year: 23.5 percent. That is because the dollar lost value against the euro. A weakening dollar is a tailwind for Americans investing abroad because each share of their foreign stock becomes worth that much more in dollars.  SO isn't this good news for domestic investors? It certainly was last year. But what happens if the dollar turns around this year and appreciates, as it did in 2005?  In that case, investors could see a big chunk of their foreign stock market gains evaporate -- even if the global stock markets are highly correlated -- simply because the dollar gained value.  This is one reason that investors should always assess several factors in the risk and return of a particular stock, said Francis M. Kinniry Jr., a principal in the investment counseling and research department at the Vanguard Group. These include its industry, its value or growth orientation, its market cap and the region where it operates.  ''While issues of style and cap size are always important, in many cases they would be secondary to geographic regions,'' Mr. Kinniry said, because stocks will always be affected by their regional economies and local currencies.  In other words, while geography may not be as important a subject as it used to be for investors, it is still one to be studied.  FUNDAMENTALLY Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.
content.title: When Those Blue Chips Aren't Made in the U.S.A.

content.text: Twenty three schools in Westchester failed to meet requirements outlined by the federal No Child Left Behind law, including four schools that were newly identified as in need of improvement, the State Education Department announced last week.  They are Ossining High School, Greenburgh Eleven High School in Dobbs Ferry, Sleepy Hollow Middle School in Tarrytown and School 23 in Yonkers.  Schools are designated in need of improvement when students do not show enough progress on statewide tests in English and mathematics. For the first time this year, schools were judged on the scores of students in the third, fifth, sixth and seventh grades, in addition to fourth, eighth and 11th graders. Not only must schools show improvement over all, but they must also meet achievement targets for component groups, like racial categories and special education.  Under the federal No Child Left Behind Act, schools that receive federal money must replace administrators or close schools if they do not improve after several years. Roosevelt High School and Emerson Middle School in Yonkers have already reorganized, and two other Yonkers middle schools, Commerce and Museum, are planning to do so this year.  ''We made the decision to redesign Roosevelt so it became two schools, with designated administrative staff for each,'' said Jerilynne Fierstein, spokeswoman for the district. ''The idea is to personalize the instruction and stay more focused on the curriculum.''  The state also removed three schools from the list because of improvements in scores, including two high schools in Yonkers, Lincoln and Gorton, that reversed several consecutive years of failure. ''We are thrilled,'' Ms. Fierstein said. ''It was quite an accomplishment for the staffs of those schools.''  Schools that do not receive federal money are not subject to No Child Left Behind sanctions, but are required to meet state demands for improvement if their students do not meet targets. Twelve of the 23 failing schools are on that list, which is referred to as ''schools requiring academic progress.''  THE WEEK
content.title: 4 Schools Added to List as Failing Under U.S. Law

content.text: When Senator Wayne Allard, Republican of Colorado, announced Monday that he would not seek re-election, the uphill battle for his party to reclaim the Senate in 2008 became an even steeper climb.  By the numbers, Republicans were already at a disadvantage. Twenty-one Republican seats will be open, compared with 12 Democratic seats. And not having a Republican incumbent on the ballot in a competitive state like Colorado complicates matters for Republicans.  Already, campaign politics is infusing substantive debates on Capitol Hill. Many of the incumbent Republican senators who have stepped forward to oppose President Bush's Iraq policy face re-election. (Senator Gordon H. Smith of Oregon started the trend late last year, followed by others, including Senator Norm Coleman of Minnesota last week.) Even before Mr. Allard's announcement, Colorado was emerging as a gateway to the West for Democrats, who have won the governor's office, two House districts and a Senate seat in the last four years. Those successes helped seal the Democratic Party's decision to hold its 2008 national convention in Denver. And now, the state will be host to one of the most closely watched Senate races in the nation, too.  JEFF ZELENY  POLITICAL ACTION
content.title: Task Gets Taller for G.O.P.

content.text: The Nets will be without Richard Jefferson, their starting small forward, for about six weeks after he has arthroscopic surgery today to remove loose fragments from his right ankle.  Jefferson is the team's second-leading scorer, and the news comes during one of the Nets' most promising stretches of the season. They beat the Orlando Magic on Saturday night for their ninth victory in 11 games and got back to .500 for the first time in two months.  The Nets (20-20) start a five-game trip to the West on Monday night with a game against the Kings in Sacramento. The trip could be an indicator of what direction the Nets, the leaders of the Atlantic Division, will take for the remainder of the season.  Jefferson, who has been bothered by ankle problems all season, chose to have the surgery now because his ankle was not getting better, said Rod Thorn, the Nets' president. Jefferson took two cortisone shots earlier this season, and Thorn said they were not working. Having the surgery now avoids the possibility of Jefferson's ankle becoming so bad that he would have to miss the rest of the season.  ''He's just not able to do the type things that he can do,'' Thorn said during a telephone interview yesterday. ''He's playing about 50, 55 percent. It's tough for him. He's a young guy, still in the early part of his career. It's mentally a tough situation.''  If Jefferson recovers in six weeks, he should be back by early March, when the Nets have a six-game trip.  Coach Lawrence Frank said his team needed to find a way to cope with Jefferson's absence.  ''Injuries happen throughout the course of the season, so regardless of how you're playing, where you're playing, that's the unfortunate reality of pro sports,'' he said by telephone.  Regardless of who plays in place of Jefferson, Frank added, ''We understand we have to be consistent.''  Jefferson missed five games early in the season after rolling his left ankle, and the second-year swingman Antoine Wright started in his place.  But Wright has fallen out of the rotation and Frank said he was not sure who would replace Jefferson. Frank said matchups could dictate his starting lineup, which may change from game to game.  Jefferson was averaging 16.1 points, 4.5 rebounds and 2.9 assists this season, all below his career averages. But he seemed to be battling through the pain and was showing flashes of his usual explosiveness. In a victory against the Knicks on Friday night, he scored 21 points.  Many credited Jefferson's improved play at times for the team's turnaround from an 11-18 record.  Jefferson's problems date to last season's playoffs, when he sprained his right ankle in the second round against the Miami Heat. He tweaked the ankle again in the off-season. The problems with the ankle resurfaced during a game against the Milwaukee Bucks in mid-December. Jefferson sat out the second half of that game because it was sore, and he missed the next game, at Toronto.  Jefferson, 26, has always prided himself on his ability to play through pain, and the nagging injury has frustrated him.  Last month, Jefferson said of his statistics: ''We're looking at some of the lows of my career. It's not acceptable.''  And after Saturday night's game, Jefferson dismissed a question about whether he would make the trip, saying: ''You're not asking me any questions about this. Come on, guys.''  Thorn said he did not believe that Jefferson's ankle problems would threaten his career.  Jefferson will be the fifth Nets player to have surgery this season. The most serious injury has been to their starting center, Nenad Krstic, who will miss the rest of the season after tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in late December. Krstic was the Nets' second-leading scorer at the time of his injury.  ''You can't lose players like Richard now, on top of Nenad,'' Thorn said. ''It's going to affect your team, obviously. We are just coming into one of the most difficult periods of our schedule. The players are going to have to play an increased role.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Will Lose Jefferson for 6 Weeks

content.text: To the Editor:  In ''The American Way of Equality'' (column, Jan. 14), David Brooks says: ''When Americans use the word 'equality,' they really mean 'fair opportunity.' When Americans use the word 'freedom,' they really mean 'opportunity.' ''  That's what one conservative columnist may think we believe. But when this American uses the word ''equality,'' I mean ''equal opportunity.'' When I use the word ''freedom,'' I'm referring to the rights guaranteed to Americans by our Constitution, including the Bill of Rights.  Freedom is precious. No American should be confused about it.  Iris Kaufman  Swampscott, Mass., Jan. 14, 2007
content.title: Defining Our Values

content.text: Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest brokerage house, capped a record earnings season for the major brokers yesterday by announcing a 68 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit.  Merrill's results, like those of its peers, were propelled by a buoyant market for mergers and acquisitions, especially buyouts, and strong results from trading and principal investments.  With the fourth-quarter results in, banks up and down Wall Street are looking more like Goldman Sachs, the competitor that everyone may love to hate but tries to imitate.  At Goldman, where fourth-quarter profit soared 98 percent, more than 64 percent of its profit last year came from trading and principal investments.  Merrill Lynch's results are starting to reflect that trend.  In the fourth quarter, investment banking and principal transactions, including net interest profit, constituted 57 percent of total net revenue, compared with only 45 percent of total revenue in the fourth quarter of 2005.  ''Trading has become a bigger part of Wall Street's business,'' said Jeffrey Harte, an analyst with Sandler O'Neill & Partners.  Over all, Merrill earned $2.35 billion, or $2.41 a share -- sharply higher than forecasts -- compared with $1.37 billion, or $1.41 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The firm also increased its dividend 40 percent, to 35 cents a common share.  Merrill shares fell $1.41, to $95.40 in trading yesterday.  On a conference call with investors, Jeffrey N. Edwards, Merrill's chief financial officer, said the results put Merrill on ''the strongest competitive footing ever as we enter 2007.''  Later, in an interview, he said: ''The most encouraging thing is the continued growth in the pipeline. It's up from the third quarter and is the highest period end pipeline we have ever had.''  For the year, Merrill reported record net earnings of $7.5 billion, up 45 percent from the previous year, on record revenue of $34.7 billion.  For the fourth quarter, trading and investment banking reported revenue of $5.4 billion, up 55 percent from the quarter a year ago and up 21 percent from the third quarter. Fixed-income revenue was up 70 percent, to $2.3 billion, while equity revenue increased 49 percent, to $1.8 billion.  Debt and equity underwriting surged, but strategic advisory services dropped a surprising 18 percent from the previous year to $286 million. Revenue in the Global Private Client business, part of global wealth management, increased 10 percent, to $3.1 billion.  Merrill attracted $22 billion in new client money, up from $17 billion a year ago, bringing total assets managed to $1.5 trillion.
content.title: Strong Merger Market Aids Merrill Lynch's 68% Profit Rise

content.text: Miriam Novalle had to close her T Salon on East 20th Street last summer when the lease ran out, but that obviously did not discourage her.  She has replaced it with T Salon & T Emporium, a large showroom on the fourth floor at 134 West 26th Street, top; Ms. Novalle is at left.  Customers will find the same elaborate tea canisters and tea accessories and the more than 400 kinds of tea she sold before.  Among them are a number of flower teas, above left, which burst into bloom in the teapot or a cup.  With the help of new investors, she has also opened T Salon, which serves teas and tea-based snacks on the lower level of the sleekly modern Té Casan shoe store at 382 West Broadway (Spring Street), above right.  Ms. Novalle plans to open another T Salon in the Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), in about eight weeks.  It will have tea for sale, a full bar for tea-based cocktails, snacks developed by Allan Susser of Miami, and a machine that makes a satisfyingly frothy tea cappuccino at the touch of a button.  FOOD STUFF
content.title: In Tins, In Cups, Teas Are In Bloom

content.text: A 19-year-old man, who is awaiting trial on charges of killing an Orange police officer last August, was sentenced to 14 years in prison on Friday for his role in an armed robbery that occurred before the officer's killing, the authorities said. The man, Raynard Brown of Orange, pleaded guilty to robbery and weapon possession last year for his role in robbing a 34-year-old woman in Orange and stealing her cellphone. He is accused of fatally shooting Detective Kieran T. Shields on Aug. 7. He has pleaded not guilty.  JOHN HOLL
content.title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Robber Is Sentenced

content.text: Amanda M. Burden, the city planning director, said yesterday that Alexandros E. Washburn would assume the newly revived post of urban design director for the Department of City Planning. Mr. Washburn, 44, is a principal in W Architecture and Landscape Architecture, a Chelsea firm. From 1996 to 2000, he was president of the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, the state agency charged with expanding the station into the General Post Office on the west side of Eighth Avenue. Now, Mr. Washburn will help evaluate the design of a new station and proposed commercial development on the east side of the avenue. Ms. Burden also named Thomas Wargo as zoning director. He was formerly a deputy director for zoning and urban design.  DAVID W. DUNLAP
content.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Names Design Chief

content.text: The latest day-in-the-life of the counterterrorism agent Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland) on ''24'' got off to a solid start in the ratings on Sunday and Monday, but opposite heavy competition Fox finished both nights in second place. According to Nielsen's estimates, the Day 6 debut earned 15.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. Sunday, a slight decline over its year-ago season premiere (16.2 million). However, Monday's two-hour second installment also drew 15.7 million viewers, a modest improvement over the fifth season's second episode (14.9 million). CBS was No. 1 on Sunday, benefiting from an overrun of its N.F.L. playoffs coverage, followed by an interview with President Bush on ''60 Minutes'' at approximately 8:30 (17.2 million). ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' (16.7 million) also outdrew ''24'' during the 9 p.m. hour Sunday. On Monday, NBC's telecast of the 64th annual Golden Globes led during every half-hour of the night and averaged 20 million viewers over all, that award show's highest ratings in three years. NBC fared less well Sunday as the second week of ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' at 8 (8.2 million) and ''The Apprentice'' at 9 (7.3 million) fell to fourth place.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Quick Start for Nimble Jack

content.text: Players in duplicate tournaments win only master points, no prizes. And they strive to attain the rank of life master. You must gain 300 points, at least 50 being silver points, which can be won only in sectional tournaments. Earlier this month the Greater New York Bridge Association ran a ''STaC'' -- for Sectional Tournaments at Clubs -- week. These pair events were played simultaneously in the clubs across the city.  The diagramed deal was played Jan. 18, and it helped Justine Cushing and Barry Rigal of New York to second place behind Joan Hight and Phyllis Young, also of New York.  When you uncover a good fit with your partner, the strength of your hand increases. There are two commonly used methods of evaluation. First, you can add points for short suits. Here each doubleton is worth one point, giving North a total of nine. This would suggest raising to two spades, with the intention of accepting a game-try by partner, or of competing to three spades if the opponents enter the auction.  Second, you can use the Losing Trick Count. You look at no more than the first three cards in every suit, counting one loser for each top honor missing. The North hand has eight losers: three spades, two hearts, one diamond and two clubs. This makes the hand worth a game-invitational raise to three spades, which was the bid chosen by Cushing. (Perhaps the best approach with a borderline hand is to underbid slightly in a pair event, where you do not push for thin games, but to overbid in a team event or Chicago, where you bid game with any excuse.)  A club, heart or high-spade start would have defeated four spades, but West had a natural diamond lead. (She was using Rusinow leads, so selected the jack, the second-highest of touching honors.)  Declarer immediately discarded two heart losers on dummy's top diamonds, then called for a club. East went up with his ace, cashed the heart ace and continued with the heart king. South ruffed, took his top trumps and club king, ruffed a club on the board (West discarded a diamond) and trumped a diamond in his hand to give this unusual finish:  When did you last see four singleton queens in a three-card end position?  South led his club jack, leaving West with no winning play. If she had ruffed, declarer would have crossruffed the last two tricks. If West had thrown the heart queen, declarer would have ruffed the club jack on the board and trumped a diamond in his hand. And when West pitched her diamond queen, South ruffed on the board and discarded his last club on the high diamond nine.  Bridge
content.title: In the Buzz of Club Activity, A Cluster of Singleton Queens

content.text: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware on Sunday became the fourth Democrat to formally announce plans to run for president next year.  ''I am running for president,'' Mr. Biden said toward the end of an appearance on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC.  ''I'm going to be Joe Biden, and I'm going to try to be the best Biden I can be,'' he said. ''If I can, I got a shot. If I can't, I lose.''  He said he would file paperwork by the end of the month to establish an exploratory committee to gather support for his bid.  Mr. Biden, who was first elected to the Senate in 1972, also sought the presidential nomination in 1988. But he dropped out of the race after admitting that he had used speeches by other politicians without attribution, and after reports that he had plagiarized while in law school.  Mr. Biden, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, joins a widening field of Democratic presidential hopefuls. The others who have officially announced their candidacies are former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio and Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa.  Other potential Democratic contenders include Senators Hilary Rodham Clinton of New York and Barack Obama of Illinois. Among Republicans, Senator John McCain of Arizona, former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, are expected to run.
content.title: Biden Joins List of Presidential Contenders

content.text: To the Editor:  Bravo to Tom Moore for ''Classroom Distinctions'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 19)!  Sainthood and martyrdom should not be prerequisites for successful teaching in high-poverty schools. While many teachers qualify on both counts, that is not the sine qua non for making a difference in a child's life.  Effective teachers will tell you they need smaller class sizes and a safe, adequately staffed, supportive environment where they are treated as professionals and asked for input.  That's what we fight for every day; and it's the least we can do to help our teachers help our students.  Randi Weingarten  President  United Federation of Teachers  New York, Jan. 22, 2007
content.title: What a Teacher Needs

content.text: WHO -- Wyndi Gundrum-Cooper, 47, a real estate agent from Ocean Isle Beach, N.C.  WHAT -- Studio condominium  WHERE -- Charleston, S.C.  I've been visiting Charleston for 15 years, I even honeymooned here, and it's a place where I've always wanted to own a home. I looked for years, but of course the closer I got to the city center, the higher the cost. I discovered this little gem about a year ago. It's 320 square feet with a 100-square-foot courtyard. When I bought it, it needed work. I redid the bathroom, since the only thing holding it up was the tile, and turned the full kitchen into a kitchenette.  The biggest thing in the apartment is the fireplace. It's 84 inches, while the kitchenette is only 54 inches across. But a big fireplace is part of the historic nature of this 200-year-old building. It's only two rooms but proved to be the hardest two rooms I've ever had to decorate. Though it's the smallest unit in the building, I wouldn't think about giving up my courtyard for a bigger space.  I live at the beach, so when I want to get away, I come here. We're two and a half hours away and make it here about twice a month. Generally my husband, Ron Cooper, and I will arrive late on a Friday night. We park the car out front and don't move it again until we leave at the end of the weekend. The condo is right on Queen Street, so we can walk to shopping on King Street and to restaurants. Charleston has a growing gallery district, and we are right in the heart of it. But when I first arrive, I just love to spend time in our home.  I never say I have a place in Charleston. I don't want people to think that I have a mansion in the city or one of the newer, grand apartments, so instead, I always say that I have ''a space'' in Charleston.  As told to Amy Gunderson  Information on properties were supplied by the owners or the listing companies  WHERE -- San Francisco  WHAT -- 1-bedroom condominium  HOW MUCH -- $549,000  Built in 2001, this Pacific Heights condo is 500 square feet and has Brazilian cherry wood floors, cherry cabinets and built-in bookcases that separate the living area from the open bedroom. There are stainless-steel appliances, granite counters, a washer and dryer, one bathroom and one parking space. The building is a long walk or a short drive from the Fisherman's Wharf area. Monthly fees are $481. Agents: Kevin Kearney and Brendon Kearney, Coldwell Banker Northern California, (415) 338-0209; www.kearneyandkearney.com.  WHERE -- Washington  WHAT -- 1-bedroom condominium  HOW MUCH -- $350,000  This first-floor, 510-square-foot condo is in a renovated 12-unit building that dates to 1910. The unit has stainless-steel appliances, bamboo floors, a private patio and one bathroom. It is in the Capitol Hill neighborhood, within walking distance of the Capitol, the Mall and the Metro. Monthly fees are $226. Agent: Federico P. Glucksmann, Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage, (202) 746-9336; www.cbmove.com.  WHERE -- Boston  WHAT -- Studio condominium  HOW MUCH -- $369,000  This 553-square-foot condo is on Commercial Street adjacent to the waterfront and the North End neighborhood. It is within walking distance of Faneuil Hall. The unit has harbor views, 10-foot ceilings, hardwood floors, one bathroom, a full kitchen and a washer and dryer. It is on the seventh floor in a 105-unit complex that was converted to condos in 1984. The complex has a roof deck. Monthly fees are $357. Parking is available for $350 a month. Agent: Carmela Laurella, Otis & Ahearn, (617) 227-6070, www.carmelalaurella.com.  WHERE -- New York  WHAT -- 1-bedroom condominium  HOW MUCH -- $725,000  A half-block from Carnegie Hall and a short walk from Central Park, this Midtown condo is 501 square feet, with south-facing windows on the 46th floor offering expansive views of Manhattan. It has hardwood floors, stainless-steel appliances, one bathroom and a dressing area. The unit has central air-conditioning, and the building has a doorman, a laundry room, a gym, a swimming pool, a conference room and a roof deck. Parking is available. Monthly fees are $385. Agent: Milena Miglietta, Bellmarc, (212) 252-1900; www.bellmarc.com.  WHERE -- Portland, Ore.  WHAT -- 1-bedroom condominium  HOW MUCH -- $315,000  This 778-square-foot, sixth-floor loft is in Portland's Pearl District, a hub of art galleries, restaurants and shops. The building dates back to 1910 and was formerly a warehouse. The loft has a separate bedroom space, a kitchen with cherry cabinets and slate countertops, one bathroom and covered parking. The unit overlooks a landscaped open-air atrium that has a fountain and benches. Monthly fees are $181. Agents: Beverly and Doug Moser, Windermere Cronin & Caplan Realty Group, (503) 789-5417; www.beverlymoser.com.  WHERE -- Seattle  WHAT -- 1-bedroom condominium  HOW MUCH -- $325,000  This 16th-floor condo is a block from the Seattle Art Museum and a few blocks from the Seattle waterfront and shopping for produce, fish and other goods at Pike Place Market. It is also close to Benaroya Hall, home to the Seattle Symphony. The unit is 510 square feet and has one bathroom, city views and one parking space. The building has an indoor swimming pool, a hot tub, a sauna, a fitness center and a business center. Monthly fees are $303. Agent: Mark Anderson, John L. Scott Real Estate, (206) 931-9807; www.mark-anderson.com.
content.title: LIVING HERE | Pied-à-terres; Small but Sufficient

content.text: THE CASTLE IN THE FOREST, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $27.95.) This remarkable novel, about the young Adolf Hitler, his family and their shifting circumstances, is Mailer's first in 10 years and his most perfect apprehension of the absolutely alien.  HOUSE OF MEETINGS, by Martin Amis. (Knopf, $23.) In Amis's novel, a Russian veteran of World War II acquaints his American stepdaughter with his grim past of rapine and violence.  THE RACE BEAT: The Press, the Civil Rights Struggle, and the Awakening of a Nation, by Gene Roberts and Hank Klibanoff. (Knopf, $30.) Two veteran journalists analyze in depth the way the news media came to play such an important role in the fight for racial justice. AFRICAN QUEEN: The Real Life of the Hottentot Venus, by Rachel Holmes. (Random House, $23.95.) A gripping case of human exploitation in 19th-century London's theater of human oddities.  FALSE SELF: The Life of Masud Khan, by Linda Hopkins. (Other Press, $35.) This biography of the dashing Anglo-Pakistani psychoanalyst reveals a man who was himself deeply troubled.  THE AVERAGED AMERICAN: Surveys, Citizens, and the Making of a Mass Public, by Sarah E. Igo. (Harvard University, $35.) How the social sciences changed the way America thinks of itself.  PAULA SPENCER, by Roddy Doyle. (Viking, $24.95.) In Doyle's novel, a Dublin woman struggles to overcome alcoholism and abuse.  LETTERS OF E. B. WHITE: Revised Edition. Originally edited by Dorothy Lobrano Guth. Revised and updated by Martha White. (HarperCollins, $35.) The expanded edition includes additional correspondence by the New Yorker writer.  THE BEST SEAT IN THE HOUSE: How I Woke Up One Tuesday and Was Paralyzed for Life, by Allen Rucker. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) At 51, Rucker was stricken with transverse myelitis.  THEY CALL ME NAUGHTY LOLA: Personal Ads From The London Review of Books. Edited and with an introduction by David Rose. (Scribner, $16.) Lonely hearts as a literary genre.  The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
content.title: Editor's Choice: Other recent books of particular interest

content.text: On paper, Gov. Jon S. Corzine may well get what he wants from the Legislature: a bill limiting annual increases in revenues from local property taxes to 4 percent.  But the proposed measure, which is most likely to be introduced in the Senate on Thursday by his fellow Democrats, is sprinkled with an array of exemptions, adjustments and waivers to the 4 percent limit.  That part of the measure seems intended to quiet some of the grumbling among local officials that they would bear the cost of easing the burden of property taxes on homeowners, yet it also falls short of what those officials have said is needed to make the governor's plan more equitable.  ''Look, we are really talking about whittling away at a portion of the tax levy for municipal services which in my town represents just 9 percent of the entire levy,'' said Louise C. Wilson, deputy mayor of Montgomery Township, adding that the rest of the tax levy goes to the local school district, which would have its own set of exemptions. ''And I know that if you start to grant so many exemptions, you're not going to have any cap.''  For one thing, some local finance officers said the provisions would not have an immediate effect because they would not be in place by July 1, the beginning of the fiscal year, and that in the long run the exemptions could jeopardize the entire effort.  Last week, in a session sponsored by the League of Municipalities, Mr. Corzine defended a 4 percent limit on annual increases in revenues from local property taxes, saying that local governments needed to find alternative sources of revenue. But by the end of the session, after several mayors complained, he warmed to the notion of allowing exemptions and waivers in some cases.  In the measure to be introduced on Thursday by the Senate president, Richard J. Codey, money set aside to cover uncollected property taxes, revenue realized from new properties on the tax rolls, a small portion of pension costs and increases in health benefits are automatically exempted.  In addition, school districts would be allowed automatic adjustments for debt service, a portion of the costs associated with increased enrollment or the opening of a new school as well as capital outlays. The school districts would also be allowed adjustments for debt service and emergencies.  The measure would also allow local governments to apply each year to the Local Finance Board or the state commissioner of education for waivers from the 4 percent cap for extraordinary circumstances like a loss of state aid, the sudden infusion of nonrecurring revenue, one-time emergency spending for ''health, safety and the public welfare,'' and cost increases resulting from mandated spending and increases in energy costs above the cap level and in equipment leases.  The decisions of the finance board and the commissioner could not be appealed.  Lou Neely, the finance director of East Brunswick, who is also the expert on property tax reform for the state League of Municipalities, called the proposed property tax measure a grab bag.  Mr. Neely said that many of the exemptions made sense, although he added that they would slow any immediate benefits to taxpayers. He said the state would be flooded with waiver requests from municipalities and school districts without a mechanism to handle them. After all, he said, ''when you are hungry and somebody throws you a crumb, you grab it.''  Local officials complained that the legislation did nothing to mitigate the costs of awards in binding arbitrations, which occur after municipalities and unions reach an impasse in labor negotiations. Localities would be required under the bill to pay the costs associated with these awards regardless of the 4 percent cap on local property taxes.  Mr. Neely and other officials wanted either a state-ordered limitation on the awards, or a provision in the bill to exempt the awards from these caps. Without such an exemption, he said, money would have to be diverted from other items financed from the property tax to pay for these awards. The proposed legislation admonishes arbitrators to ''consider as a primary factor in their awards'' the effect on tax levy limitations. Similarly, it addresses increases in employee health costs faced by local governments, and encourages local officials to renegotiate contracts.  Mr. Neely said that the ''state has precluded us from reopening contracts in the past, and it is nice that they are now letting us do it.''  ''But,'' he added, ''they ought to say to arbitrators that this is a hard cap and you can't grant awards over it.''  Still, most local officials conceded that the measure would be approved.  Mayor Gary Passanante of Somerdale said property taxes would not ease up any time soon, primarily because they account for about 46 percent of local budgets, more than the national average of 30 percent.  Borrowing phrasing frequently used by Governor Corzine, Mr. Passanante said: ''Our benchmark for accomplishing reform that is for the common good is doing something that gets us closer to the national average of 30 percent. But nothing in the governor's package does this.''  POLITICAL MEMO
content.title: A Cap on Property Taxes May Have a Few Loopholes

content.text: A photograph with an Inside summary on the front page of last Sunday's section, about a couple looking for a rental near a park where they could walk their dog, carried an erroneous credit.
